dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So the EU's massive stimulus package, right, it's got this huge seven hundred and fifty billion euro Recovery and Resilience Facility at its core.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So the E U's massive stimulus package, right, it's got this huge seven hundred and fifty billion euro Recovery and Resilience Facility at its core.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and that's the thing, like, they're finally doing joint borrowing, which is a huge deal after, you know, Germany and others blocked it for so long during the debt crisis.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and that's the thing, like, they're finally doing joint borrowing, which is a huge deal after, you know, Germany and others blocked it for so long during the debt crisis.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Such fiscal integration had also seemed essential during the debt crises faced by Greece, Ireland, Spain, Portugal, and Italy from 2010 onward, but Germany and other wealthier member states rejected the idea. By adopting a stimulus package that involves explicit joint borrowing and fiscal transfers between countries, EU member states seem to have overcome a historic taboo of European integration.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, it's a historic shift. But the article points out this, um, pretty glaring blind spot—it's all inward-looking solidarity.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, it's a historic shift. But the article points out this, um, pretty glaring blind spot-it's all inward-looking solidarity.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Just as the stimulus measures announced by US President Joe Bidens new administration are predominantly aimed at the US economy, the EU package expresses solidarity within Europe, with little concern for the rest of the world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, like, there's almost no concern for the rest of the world. It reminds me of Biden's US-centric stimulus, honestly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, like, there's almost no concern for the rest of the world. It reminds me of Biden's U S-centric stimulus, honestly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Just as the stimulus measures announced by US President Joe Bidens new administration are predominantly aimed at the US economy, the EU package expresses solidarity within Europe, with little concern for the rest of the world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And that's the problem. They're setting up these big funds—Horizon Europe, EU4Health—but it's all for the bloc. Meanwhile, developing countries are just left out in the cold.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And that's the problem. They're setting up these big funds-Horizon Europe, EU4Health-but it's all for the bloc. Meanwhile, developing countries are just left out in the cold.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There will be support for research and innovation via the Horizon Europe program, and for climate and digital transitions through the Just Transition Fund and the Digital Europe Program, respectively. The package will also establish a new health program, EU4Health, and a Recovery and Resilience Facility to disburse most of the Next Generation EU funds.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And it gets worse with vaccines. The EU actually tried to bypass COVAX to secure doses for itself first.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it gets worse with vaccines. The E U actually tried to bypass C O V A X to secure doses for itself first.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Although European media rarely mention this the EU sought to bypass the fair distribution system established by the COVID-19 Vaccine Global Access Facility (COVAX), and purchase vaccines directly from pharmaceutical firms, thus denying supplies to the rest of the world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which is just, uh, incredibly short-sighted. Blocking wider production by protecting patents means more variants, longer pandemic for everyone, including Europe.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is just, uh, incredibly short-sighted. Blocking wider production by protecting patents means more variants, longer pandemic for everyone, including Europe.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Worse, by insisting on preserving pharmaceutical companies patent rights for vaccines developed with government subsidies and on the back of public research, the EU is helping to prevent the expansion of vaccine production to levels that would enable the entire world to be rapidly immunized. This would dramatically increase global supply and reduce the risk of dangerous coronavirus mutations, thus ensuring a much quicker end to the pandemic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: They're acting like they can fix their own house and ignore the global neighborhood burning down.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They're acting like they can fix their own house and ignore the global neighborhood burning down.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: The article suggests some fixes, though, like using a fraction of that stimulus to cancel bilateral debt for poorer nations.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The article suggests some fixes, though, like using a fraction of that stimulus to cancel bilateral debt for poorer nations.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For starters, they could set aside just a small fraction of their large stimulus packages to eliminate bilateral debt owed by poorer countries, and actively pursue sovereign-debt resolution for private creditors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Or expanding Special Drawing Rights at the IMF. But it requires thinking of aid as investment, not charity.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Or expanding Special Drawing Rights at the I M F. But it requires thinking of aid as investment, not charity.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: More broadly, they must stop thinking of foreign aid as a gift or charity, and instead allocate funds for global public investment to meet common international goals. And they could immediately work toward significantly expanding developing economies access to foreign exchange through a large new allocation of Special Drawing Rights by the International Monetary Fund.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which they're just... not doing. It's this fortress Europe mentality, even after Brexit removed one of the biggest opponents to integration.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which they're just... not doing. It's this fortress Europe mentality, even after Brexit removed one of the biggest opponents to integration.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Brexit probably also helped, because the United Kingdom had traditionally opposed EU-level fiscal expansion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, you'd think greater unity would make them more outward-looking, but it seems to have had the opposite effect.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, you'd think greater unity would make them more outward-looking, but it seems to have had the opposite effect.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But greater unity has also reinforced Europes belief that it can go it alone in charting a path out of the crisis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's a massive missed opportunity. A sustainable recovery has to be global, or it's not sustainable at all.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a massive missed opportunity. A sustainable recovery has to be global, or it's not sustainable at all.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Even for wealthy regions like Europe, any plausible vision of a sustainable post-pandemic future necessarily requires international solidarity.
